Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 4, 2023 Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following. Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date. Updated Case
Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information,
needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the
safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Six of six foster care files reviewed did not have the corresponding DHS-1105
documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
08/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
2

Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Parents who are a member of
a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and older. •
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
Six foster care files and twenty service plans were reviewed. Four of six files and five
of twenty service plans documented late or missing signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
08/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child's
placement date to the following: • Foster care provider. •
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care. The actual date the medical
passport is provided must be documented in the electronic
case management record.
Six foster care files and 13 medical passports were reviewed. Three of six files did
not document updated medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
08/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan on August 22, 2022, in
response to those violations established during the renewal inspection completed
on August 8, 2022. The current inspection established three repeat violations and
they are as follows, FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings, FOM 722-08D
Treatment Plans, and FOM 801-03 Medical passports. The agency CAP was
successful in preventing repeat violations for the following rules and policy: R
400.12311 Parent/Agency Agreement, R 400.12326 Borrowed Home, R
400.12418 Development of Treatment Plans, R 400.12502 Program Statement, R
400.12503 Policy and Procedure, R 400.123510 Independent Living Contract,
FOM 722-16 DHS-1295 Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, and FOM 722-06H
Case Contact.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators annual assessment was received and reviewed. The
assessment was thorough in addressing their corrective action plan stemming
from their renewal inspection. The assessment identified staffing transitions as a
challenge for the agency.
Financial Overview
N/A as DHHS local office.
Staff Interviews
Staff reported that they receive supportive supervision and feel they are part of a
high functioning and supportive team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a local DHHS office. The agency is spacious and well maintained.
CHRI documentation was stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst established two 2 safety alerts during here visits to the homes.
Safety Alert #1. A safety alert was generated on July 7, 2023, as the home was
lacking a carbon monoxide detector.
Resolution: The agency visited the home on the same date and a detector was
installed. Photos were provided and uploaded.
4

Safety Alert #2. A safety alert was generated on July 13, 2023, as guns were found
not to be trigger locked and stored in a solid gun case.
Resolution: Trigger locks were installed, and the guns locked in a solid gun case.
Photos were provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
